desc: AXIN2, a tumor suppressor involved in WNT signaling, is mutated at low frequencies in a diverse range of cancers.

AXIN2 encodes Axis Inhibition Protein 2, a key component of the beta-catenin (CTNNB1) destruction complex. Negative regulation of beta-catenin by the complex in the absence of a extracellular stimulus is central to Wnt signaling (PMID: 20128690, 23169527). In the complex, AXIN2 and AXIN1 provide scaffolding and bind to the tumor suppressor, APC (PMID: 14600025) enabling CTNNB1 destruction (PMID: 9734785). AXIN2 is involved in the TGFβ and SAPK pathways (PMID: 15735151). As part of the AXIN-HIPK2-TP53 complex, the protein also plays a role in the control of cell growth, apoptosis and development (PMID: 15526030). Somatic mutations in this gene have been associated with colorectal cancer (PMID: 11017067). Germline mutations in AXIN2 have been associated with gastrointestinal and colorectal cancers (PMID: 25236910, 21541676) as well as familial tooth agenesis and predisposition to colorectal cancer (PMID: 15042511). No drugs targeting the Wnt pathway have yet been approved (PMID: 24981364). AXIN2 expression has been shown to predict prostate cancer recurrence (PMID: 26771938).
